question: What rock forms when pressure squeezes sediment grains together?

content.source_1: Buried sediments experience overburden pressure that squeezes mineral grains together and reduces the space between them; this squeezing is called compaction.
content.source_2: Compaction together with cementation constitutes lithification, the process by which loose sediment is transformed into sedimentary rock.
content.source_3: As sediments are compacted and cemented during burial, they lithify; lithified sediments are sedimentary rock.
content.source_4: Compaction alone—squeezing grains together under pressure—reduces porosity and expels pore water but does not produce a rock in the absence of cementation.
content.source_5: Cementation requires minerals to precipitate from pore fluids and bind grains; squeezing alone supplies pressure but not cement.
content.source_6: In many shallow-burial settings, sediments can be strongly compacted yet remain unconsolidated until sufficient diagenetic cement precipitates in their pore spaces.
